for (i in array) { let answer = e.answers_json[answers.indexOf(array[i])]; if (call(answer)) { wantedAnswers++; } } return wantedAnswers; } hustoncrazyCount = (array, call = a => a.fields.hustoncrazy) => { array = array.filter(a=>a); } let vpName = "ERROR YOU DIDN'T SET ME"; vpTable = { "Richard Nixon" : vpName, "George McGovern" : "Sargent Shriver", "Dr. Spock" : "Julius Hobson", "John Schmitz" : "Thomas Anderson", "Hubert Humphrey" : "Henry M. Jackson", "Edmund Muskie" : "John Tunney", "George Wallace" : "Sam Yorty", "Ted Kennedy" : "Thomas Eagleton", "Shirley Chisholm" : "Pat Lucey", "Henry Jackson" : "Moon Landrieu", "John Lindsay" : "Abraham Ribicoff", "Dr. Spock" : "Julius Hobson", "George C. Pig II", "Bobby Seale" : "Raymond Hewitt", } vpTableHistorical = { "Richard Nixon" : "Spiro Agnew", "George McGovern" : "Sargent Shriver", "Dr. Spock" : "Julius Hobson", "John Schmitz" : "Thomas Anderson", } function onGameWindowChangeCandidates() { const resultsTableHolder = document.getElementById("overall_details_container"); if(!resultsTableHolder || resultsTableHolder.classList.contains("done")) { return; } resultsTableHolder.classList.add("done"); const resultsTable = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[3].childNodes[3].children[0]; for(let i = 0; i < resultsTable.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTable.children[i]; let name = row.firstChild.innerText; row.insertCell(1); if(name) { name = name.replaceAll("-", "").trim(); console.log("name is:" + name) } if(i == 0) { row.children[1].innerHTML = `Running Mate`; } else { row.children[1].innerHTML = vpTable[name]; } } const resultsTableHistorical = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[5].childNodes[3].children[0]; for(let i = 0; i < resultsTableHistorical.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTableHistorical.children[i]; let name = row.childNodes[1].innerText; row.insertCell(1); if(name) { name = name.replaceAll("-", "").trim(); } if(i == 0) { row.children[1].innerHTML = `Running Mate`; } else { row.children[1].innerHTML = vpTableHistorical[name]; } } } const gameWindowNode = document.getElementById("game_window"); const candidateWatcherConfig = { attributes: true, childList: true, subtree: true }; const candidateObserver = new MutationObserver(onGameWindowChangeCandidates); candidateObserver.observe(gameWindowNode, candidateWatcherConfig); // constructs endings based on header and pages construct = (a = 1) => { e.page = e.page + a < e.pages.length ? e.page + a : 0 let html = e.header; html += e.pages[e.page] + "
"; if (e.page > 0) { html += `` } if (e.page < e.pages.length - 1) { html += `` } if (e.image == true) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0] if (candImg) { candImg.remove() $("#final_results_description")[0].style = ` text-align:left; width: 70%; text-overflow: ellipsis; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; ` } }, 10) else if (e.image) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0]; if (candImg) candImg.src = e.image; }, 10) return html; } endingConstructor = (a = 1) => { $("#final_results_description")[0].innerHTML = construct(a); } // ENDINGS -- this is slightly more reliable than the ending code method e.multiple_endings = true; endingPicker = (out, totv, aa, quickstats) => { //out = "win", "loss", or "tie" for your candidate //totv = total votes in entire election //aa = all final overall results data //quickstat = relevant data on candidate performance (format: your candidate's electoral vote count, your candidate's popular vote share, your candidate's raw vote total) /* e.header = "

Whittier Cardinals vs. Harvard-Westlake Wolverines, December 9, 1930

" e.pages = ["

Graves: Here's Logue back to throw... pocket collapsed, and down he goes, as Jerry Courtenay gets there.

Moorhead: Courtenay is havin' a heckuva day.

Graves: Isn't he?

", "

Moorhead: Tell ya, he was the guy, course, got that, that interception for the touchdown, and the great run, and the great jump, and here, he's gets a pass rush over Whittier’s best offensive lineman. That's their left tackle, Paul Sweeney. He just got Sweeney goin' back, and then he just he came right off of him, and made the, made the sack on Logue. If he doesn't watch out, he's gonna be the Los Angeles County defensive player of the week.

Graves: Maybe of the year.

", "

Moorhead: Yeah, because when you get numbers like that, you know, and that's what every defensive lineman wants is, is numbers. And of course you get the sack numbers. But then, when you get the interception numbers, and the interception for a return numbers, now you're talkin' numbers, now you're talkin', you got some numbers.

", "

Graves: Whittier just took a timeout, stopped the clock. The Cardinals better hope they can pin ‘em back hard. Remember, because of the tiebreaker, Whitter needs to win if they’re going to advance. Harvard-Westlake doesn’t need to. They can tie and still move on, and they’re only down by three.

Moorhead: Tommy Petty, back to punt. And he's done well against the wind. He goes, and… they blocked him! Harvard-Westlake gets the ball at the 20!

…

", "

Graves: And… good! With time expired, that’s your final score: 10 Whittier, 10 Harvard-Westlake. The Wolverines advance with the tiebreaker, and the Cardinals, for another year, see their season end early.

Moorhead: The Cardinals put up more of a fight than I think anyone expected, but, in the end, it just wasn’t enough. It’s really gotta be a heartbreaker for those seniors, you know, even the ones you don’t see play.

", "

Graves: Speaking of that, I heard about one guy, number 12. Second-string player. Never lettered. Never even started a game. Still went to practice every darn day. They said he was the most spirited warmer on the team. You don’t see guys like that at Harvard-Westlake.

Moorhead: You sure as heck don’t, John. But that’s Whittier, right? You always see them try hard, but it’s just not enough. Not for the win.

Graves: Those moments are for other people.

Eulogy by former President McGovern at the funeral of President Nixon, March 18th 1993

" e.pages = ["

To President Nixon’s family, President and Senator Dole, and President Cuomo: We are here today to celebrate an extraordinary man. Richard Nixon truly embodied our American values, particularly in defending our allies around the world. I am deeply touched to see just how many of them are gathered here today. General Pinochet, President Somoza, President Marcos, General Suharto, Prime Minister Ian Smith, and Prime Minister Papadopoulos, I thank you.

I think today of words from President Theodore Roosevelt, about the man in the arena. I know President Nixon valued these words closely: who at the best knows in the end the triumphs of high achievements and who at the worst, if he fails, at least fails while daring greatly.", "I think today of the unparalleled courage President Nixon took in 1972. Putting integrity over politics, and the health of the nation over the health of his party, President Nixon opened his heart to the American people. In that brief moment, it brought political consequences. But in the great arc of history, with one little push, Richard Nixon set it back on its curve towards justice.

", "I was honored to have been in the arena with President Nixon, and I was deeply humbled by his advice over my time in office. President Nixon never flinched from criticisms, and made sure I knew when he thought I was making a mistake. Those calls came more often than the ones where he told me I was doing something right. But what I valued most, was what so many Americans cherished about Richard Nixon: his unwavering commitment to the truth, and to this country.

May God's grace be with you in all the days ahead.

- President McGovern (1973-1981)

"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_7.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 0 && out == "loss" && watergateconfessLevel == 0 && quickstats[0] < 100) { e.header = "

Remarks by the President to Reporters, Washington, D.C., January 20 1981

" e.pages = ["

REPORTER: Madame President!…Richard Nixon has died. Richard Nixon has passed away.

THE PRESIDENT: He just died?

REPORTER: Yes.

THE PRESIDENT: Wow. I didn’t know that. I just, uhh, you’re telling me for the first time…He led an amazing life. What else can you say? He was…whether you agreed or not, he led an amazing life. Uh, I’m actually sad to hear that. I am sad to hear that. Thank you very much.

- President Jane Fonda, 1981-1989"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_8.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 0 && out == "loss" && watergateconfessLevel == 0 && quickstats[0] > 99) { e.header = "

November

" e.pages = ["

We began to get a sense of just how kooky things were getting once we knew Missouri was in play. Missouri had been Eagleton's state, after all, and the McGovern name had been dead to them ever since the Affair. . .Eagleton, meanwhile, had gone completely quiet ever since he'd been booted, and he wasn't any use to anyone. But McGovern was contending in Missouri, he'd made it too close to call, and it was there that the first glimpse of the Hope started flashing in the eyes of the younger staffers.

I'd gone up to the press room on the ninth floor to see the first results come in, but by midnight the dope I'd scored off some of the others hiding behind the curtains at the back of the room was wearing off and I needed a drink – a real drink – to get my nerves back in order.", "This whole night was the point of The Work – the point of moving to D.C., the point of following McGovern around from New Hampshire to California to Miami and all the rest – and I couldn't be missing The Work because of nerves. I wound up at the hotel bar where I told the bartender to give me the strongest bottle of whiskey under the counter and that I'd pay him back with the winnings I got from my bets that morning. I'd made one with Frank that McGovern would carry West Virginia, one with Gary that he'd carry Colorado, and one with the local bookie that McGovern would win at all, along with a dozen more with the other reporters on the Zoo Plane on counties, margins, the 49ers-Colts game that Sunday. . .

", "

I had tried to make a bet with McGovern that he'd take California, but he'd told me that a Serious Candidate shouldn't be taking bets on his own election, let alone be seen with a drug-crazed freak besides him in front of the other reporters. . .

By midnight I was three-quarters of the way through a bottle and into a tab of mescaline, looking up at the TV screens that, occasionally, would broadcast the big dining hall where everyone had set up to wait. There's a real electricity in the air here at McGovern's HQ, where they've eagerly been watching for further movement towards the Senator... while in San Clemente we haven't been able to get hold of the President. . .and now we've heard that our desk has called Illinois, that McGovern is going to win in Illinois, and this crowd here in California is about to hear it. . .

", "Holy God, Illinois. The campaign had put Gene Pokorny, the Wisconsin wizard who had the best argument out of anyone on the staff for most valuable player in the early running, on Illinois, and he'd delivered again – without Daley, without Meany. Holy God, Illinois, and then the crowd downstairs heard it and the roar was so loud that it shook the building and knocked my bottle off the table and onto the floor, and I realized that I had heard that roar before, at the Super Bowl in January – but that had been with 80,000 Cowboys fans, and this crowd of a thousand young geeks and hicks had matched them.

", "

That much noise from that small of a crowd fired some left-behind section of brain that I'd dropped in Miami in July, and I felt my legs carrying me towards the stairs again. . .and then I was down in the pit with the other freaks, hazed in pot smoke and sweat and acid, and I'd made it back to that beating in July again where it had just gone on and on – but this time was different, because now they were calling Ohio for McGovern, and Pennsylvania, and Connecticut, and Washington, and Montana and California , and suddenly it was all over and the crowd wasn't a crowd anymore, it was a mass of joy and drugs and free love and Vindication — Vindication that Nixon was a crook, Vindication that McGovern was for real, Vindication that the hippies had it right all along, Vindication that America, for all its pigheaded bullshit and ignorance and meanness, could see things the same way the students did.

", "I couldn't find anyone that night, and I couldn't find McGovern most of all. . .I was told, later, by a couple staffers watching the fireworks blow up overhead with tabs on their tongues, that he'd disappeared, been raptured, maybe died of joy, and that the man on the TV a few hundred feet behind them that was promising a more honest America wasn't George McGovern but instead a hastily found body-double sourced from the Secret Service. . .I'd lost track somewhere around there and dropped my notebook in the pile of the dining hall floor, where it was returned to me the night after, soaked in champagne and cheap beer. . .and my memory was too shot through to put anything else together that wasn't written about in the notebook together. But it didn't matter. A hundred other journalists did Objective Journalism that night, and Objective Journalism was always my friend Raoul Duke's angle.

", "

What I got from that night was a feeling that I never thought I would have and, barring that night, have never had again – the feeling that I lived in Nixon's Ideal America, where the Good Guys won and stories ended, where the wicked and evil were driven from power with clubs and hammers and batons, where the hero gets his due and the villain, the crooked swine who surrounded himself with goons and criminals, who burnt through lives and decency and morality like firewood on Christmas, could be rejected by those he'd spent his whole life clawing and grasping and biting and gnashing for acceptance, for worship, for respect from. From the moment the last state fell perfectly into place to the moment the papers hit the shelves the next morning, that feeling – the Hope – was inescapable, untouchable. For a second in time, We had won and They had lost, and that second would carry with us for the rest of our lives.

"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_9.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 0 && out == "win" && quickstats[0] < 350 && watergateconfessLevel == 0) { e.header = "

Conversation between President Nixon and CIA Director Richard Helms, May 19 1973

" e.pages = ["

NIXON: Walters, is he on this?

HELMS: Yes, Mr. President. He did fine work for us in Brazil during the Goulart government back in—

NIXON: Good. He knows all about the dirty tricks department then.

HELMS: Yes.

NIXON: You know, back under Eisenhower they would be thanking us for this, the bastards.

KISSINGER: That’s right.

NIXON: We just move a few votes one way, pay off a few officers, I mean that’s all this is. That Allende is a pain in the goddamn ass—

", "KISSINGER: Well he’s a communist—

NIXON: —and pro-Castro! Now McGovern and Fulbright are crying about that son-of-a-bitch over on the Hill, saying we’re out to get him. Well of course we’re out to get him! That bastard goes on national television, using it for the worst goddamn propaganda purposes.

KISSINGER: He’s played a masterful game, that Allende—

NIXON: [Inaudible]

HELMS: Well, we tried covert action to try and assist the opposition—

", "

NIXON: Didn’t goddamn work, did it? That’s why we’ve got this mess today with Allende. You know, I am totally supportive of the dirty tricks department. I know all about Guatemala in ‘54, or Iran with Mossadegh. Everything with Diem. I know all of that. Why you clowns can’t get it right in Chile—

KISSINGER: Well with these investigations, it’s going to be a hell of a lot more difficult [inaudible].

NIXON: I know, I know. That bastard McGovern. He feels like he can say whatever he wants now after that election. A couple more states going his way, and he would be sitting in here right now. Christ. He just needs to shut his mouth.", "

HELMS: I understand perfectly.

KISSINGER: [Inaudible]

", "

NIXON: No, I’m serious. You do these things in every little country around the world, but you let these clowns tear this one apart. Put a goddamn end to it. I’m tired of playing around with these bastards. McGovern, Church, Fulbright. They’re animals!

HELMS: I entirely agree.

", "This conversation was played repeatedly by the prosecution in the trial of Richard Helms in 1977. Helms was convicted of multiple felonies and given a 25-year sentence. A subordinate code-named MH/WHIP was rendered mute after attempted to swallow a cyanide capsule when he was caught trying to lace Senator McGovern’s toothbrush with LSD generated by the Technical Services Division of the CIA (1947-1978)."] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_10.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 0 && out == "win" && quickstats[0] < 350 && watergateconfessLevel == 1 && quickstats[0] < 535) { e.header = "

CBS News, November 8, 1972

" e.pages = ["

Cronkite: Welcome back. America voted yesterday, and in case you missed it, here’s the headline: it’s always close with Nixon. It was too close to call last night, but we got enough returns from the close states to declare that he’ll come out ahead over Senator McGovern. The White House hasn’t given us a time for his victory speech—supposedly the President came down with a “minor illness” over the night—so, in the meantime, we’ll cover the other story of the night. Democrats practically swept the table in the Senate. Absent New Mexico, which is still too close to call, they have held all of their seats, while flipping five from Republicans. One of these victors, former Senator and Democratic candidate for Senate in Oregon, Wayne Morse, joins me now, phoning in from Portland. Mr. Senator, what do you make of these results?", "Senator-elect Morse: Thanks for having me, Walter. First, I’d just like to once again thank the people of Oregon for giving me the honor to represent them in the Senate again, and commend Senator Hatfield for running a well-fought and honorable campaign. Now, broadly, I think these results show that, while Americans trust President Nixon as a leader, not many of us trust his policies. When I’m back in the Senate, I’ll be sure to make sure that the President follows through on his promises of peace.

Cronkite: What do you make of that the President came so close to losing against a challenger almost no-one gave a chance?", "Senator-elect Morse: Well, to me, it shows that things have changed in a way the President might not fully understand. I think about my last two races. Four years ago, I was defeated by Senator Packwood—well, before he was Senator Packwood—on the charge that I was too opposed to the war in Vietnam. This year, both Senator Hatfield and I proudly stood against it. In light of this, the President should be well advised to stay on the straight and narrow.

Cronkite: Or else what, Senator?

Senator-elect Morse: Let’s hope it doesn’t come to that.

Excerpt from The Straightjacket: How The World’s Greatest Deliberative Body Stopped a Reckless and Arrogant Presidency, by Robert C. Byrd, 1995"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_11.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 0 && watergateconfessLevel == 1 && out == "win" && quickstats[0] > 350 && quickstats[0] < 535) { e.header = "

A speech by the President in Miami, on the one year anniversary of the humanitarian operation in Cuba and the death of President Richard Nixon, January 11th, 1995

" e.pages = ["

PRESIDENT: Good morning. Today is an important marker in the history of freedom in the Americas. Today marks one year since the beginning of a coalition uniting this region, determined to aid desperate people against tyrannical regimes. After one year, we have made enormous progress. From the five years before this operation began, the communist Castro government refused entry to badly-needed humanitarian relief. It was like a stranglehold around an entire country. Our allies in the hemisphere and the United States could not stand idly by. Today, as our brave armed forces move forward near Camaguey, I would like a moment of silence for us to say a prayer for our troops.

[Silence]", "

PRESIDENT: Thank you.

REPORTER: Mr. President, the Nixon Library just put out a statement five minutes ago that former President Richard Nixon has passed away. Do you have any statement on that?

[Aide whispering to the President] ", "

PRESIDENT: That saddens me, Jeff, I’m just hearing that now. My thoughts are with the Nixon family, and I pray they are afforded privacy in this difficult moment. You know I served with President Nixon, as Ambassador to the United Nations, then as chair of the Republican National Committee, later Ambassador to what was then the Soviet Union, and finally as Director of the Central Intelligence Agency. I was all over government in those years, but what was always a constant was Richard Nixon. His presence was—it, well, it’s impossible to describe. He was a brilliant man, and watching him lead up close was indescribable.

", "I’ve been honored to receive his advice as president myself, and truly humbled by his incredible knowledge of world affairs. But, especially, uh Cuba. President Nixon was always determined—in a way his predecessors weren’t—on supporting a free Cuba, one rid of its cowardly totalitarian regime. He was devoted to the men who fought on the beaches in the Bay of Pigs invasion, and—I can say this as someone who knew him personally—was disgusted by what he regarded as a lack of will to follow through on that support from some corners in Washington. The greatest memorial to President Nixon would be a free Havana. I’ll certainly be attending the funeral, and I can’t speak to former President Rumsfeld or President Brown, but I know they valued President Nixon’s advice as much as I did.

"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_12.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 0 && watergateconfessLevel == 0 && out == "win" && quickstats[0] > 350 && quickstats[0] < 535) { e.header = "

THE DEATH OF RICHARD NIXON: NOTES ON THE PASSING OF AN AMERICAN MONSTER.... HE WAS A LIAR AND A QUITTER, AND HE SHOULD HAVE BEEN BURIED AT SEA.... BUT HE WAS, AFTER ALL, THE PRESIDENT.

" e.pages = ["

It was Richard Nixon who got me into politics, and now that he's gone, I feel lonely. He was a giant in his way. As long as Nixon was politically alive -- and he was, all the way to the end -- we could always be sure of finding the enemy on the Low Road. There was no need to look anywhere else for the evil bastard. He had the fighting instincts of a badger trapped by hounds. The badger will roll over on its back and emit a smell of death, which confuses the dogs and lures them in for the traditional ripping and tearing action. But it is usually the badger who does the ripping and tearing. It is a beast that fights best on its back: rolling under the throat of the enemy and seizing it by the head with all four claws.", "

That was Nixon's style -- and if you forgot, he would kill you as a lesson to the others. Badgers don't fight fair, bubba. That's why God made dachshunds.

If the right people had been in charge of Nixon's funeral, his casket would have been launched into one of those open-sewage canals that empty into the ocean just south of Los Angeles. He was a swine of a man and a jabbering dupe of a president. Nixon was so crooked that he needed servants to help him screw his pants on every morning. Even his funeral was illegal. He was queer in the deepest way. His body should have been burned in a trash bin.

", "Kissinger was only one of the many historians who suddenly came to see Nixon as more than the sum of his many squalid parts. He seemed to be saying that History will not have to absolve Nixon, because he has already done it himself in a massive act of will and crazed arrogance that already ranks him supreme, along with other Nietzschean supermen like Hitler, Jesus, Bismarck and the Emperor Hirohito. These revisionists have catapulted Nixon to the status of an American Caesar, claiming that when the definitive history of the 20th century is written, no other president will come close to Nixon in stature. He will dwarf FDR and Truman, according to one scholar from Duke University.", "

It was all gibberish, of course. Nixon was no more a Saint than he was a Great President. He was more like Sammy Glick than Winston Churchill. He was a cheap crook and a merciless war criminal who bombed more people to death in Laos and Cambodia than the U.S. Army lost in all of World War II, and he denied it to the day of his death. When students at Kent State University, in Ohio, protested the bombing, he connived to have them attacked and slain by troops from the National Guard.

", "Some people will say that words like scum and rotten are wrong for Objective Journalism -- which is true, but they miss the point. It was the built-in blind spots of the Objective rules and dogma that allowed Nixon to slither into the White House in the first place. He looked so good on paper that you could almost vote for him sight unseen. He seemed so all-American, so much like Horatio Alger, that he was able to slip through the cracks of Objective Journalism. You had to get Subjective to see Nixon clearly, and the shock of recognition was often painful.", "He has poisoned our water forever. Nixon will be remembered as a classic case of a smart man shitting in his own nest. But he also shit in our nests, and that was the crime that history will burn on his memory like a brand. By disgracing and degrading the Presidency of the United States, by fleeing the White House like a diseased cur, Richard Nixon broke the heart of the American Dream.", "- Hunter S. Thompson, originally published in Rolling Stone, 1994"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_13.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 0 && watergateconfessLevel == 0 && out == "win" && quickstats[0] > 534) { e.header = "

And here at NBC election night headquarters...

" e.pages = ["The presidential suite at the Shoreham was comfortable. He’d laid himself out along the couch. A glass of scotch whisky sat on the end table, perspiration leaving a small ring around it. Mitchell and the boys had secluded themselves to one of the other available rooms, partly out of courtesy and partly to spare themselves his attention. Pat and the girls were—. Oh, why the hell did he care where Pat was? He was too focused on the television, on the dull, monotone of those bastards Chancellor and Brinkley, on the slow count of the vote and his rising numbers.

“With one percent of the vote in, now Mr. Nixon leading better than two to one over McGovern…” The television intoned.

", "

He continued watching. He finished and poured another scotch whiskey. The states were coming in, one after the other. There was Ohio—uptight, patronizing bastards—and Maryland—a mob state, home to that moron Agnew—and South Dakota—hicks and rubes. He couldn’t imagine why anyone would willingly live in any of these places, but he didn’t begrudge their votes. Red spread, cancer-like, across the map.

They were replaying a video of him and Pat voting at the Concordia Library in California now, the announcer gushing over the size of the crowds and how he’d filled out a newspaper-sized ballot. A Potemkin gesture. He grimaced when they showed a shot of him dropping his ballot and having to reach down to grab it, but it didn’t matter. There would be consequences in due time.

", "

“We may,” he was aware of the television talking again, though the world around him felt fuzzy. He spilled scotch on the couch, “be on the verge of a truly historic election. West Virginia and Massachusetts, both long-time Democratic strongholds, are too close to call…”

The president stumbled into the bathroom, feeling his heart thud as he splashed water on his face. Those bastards at NBC had given up any hope of McGovern winning now. Yes, the game now was to humiliate him at his greatest triumph. They wanted to make him into a goddamn clown, but he wouldn’t let them. He wouldn’t—.

“We can now confirm it.”", "Chancellor’s tinny voice echoed from around the corner. “Richard Milhous Nixon, 37th president of the United States, has won all 50 states. Not since the days of the Founding Fathers has such a triumph been...”

“YOU’RE GODDAMN RIGHT.” He slammed his fist into the bathroom mirror. Spiderweb cracks erupted from the surface. His face reflected back at him one thousand times. He could feel pain in his right hand, but he didn’t care. It was just like Watergate, just a little pain, a little annoyance, that would fade in time. Then, at the end, he would be there, standing tall.

In the shattered mirror, he could see the future. He would serve eight full years. The Watergate business would fall into the dustbin of history, the would-be whistleblowers ignored or eliminated.", "Then, he would pass the torch to Connally, but not really. He’d still be there in the party, in the bureaucracy, in the shadows, controlling and cajoling. Then he would replace Connally with Reagan and Reagan with Bush and Bush with Dole. An unbroken chain.

And what was in the foreground? A nation of Orthogonians, of Nixonites, stared back at him. The room was crowded with them, standing shoulder to shoulder, ready to inflict their misery upon the world.

Nixon grabbed a hand towel, wrapped it around his hand, and called Mitchell and Safire to make some adjustments to his victory speech. There was work to do."] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_14.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 0 && watergateconfessLevel == 1 && out == "win" && quickstats[0] > 534) { e.header = "

Danbury Correctional Institute, 20 January 1973

" e.pages = ["

Goddamn, this soup is cold. The frigid winter climate outside didn’t help matters, but did the cooks really have to make something this inedible? Maybe they’re trying to put poison in it. At least, that’s what Gordon Liddy told himself. He didn’t even really believe this one, but Christ, he needed something to take his mind off that revolting spectacle on the TV.

Huddled around the stereo, Danbury’s finest all watched Richard Nixon take the Oath of Office for his second term as president. A few of them were cracking jokes about Liddy, one of the prison’s most high-profile prisoners. He had just gotten off the bus here only days earlier, after the authorities unexpectedly sped up his processing. They said it was because of some seasonal backlog getting cleared, whatever that fucking meant. But Gordon knew why he was being shoved away...

", "

Gordon would never forget that September evening. Few men can say that the President of the United States threw them personally under the proverbial Air Force One on national television to a live audience of a hundred million. How many more can say that that president then went on to win not just a smashing landslide two months later, but to win every state? After all he did for that bastard from Whittier….

Gordon could already see it now. Richard Nixon with a shit-eating grin, signing Ted Kennedy’s socialized medicine into law. Richard Nixon, the liberal, making Shirley Chisholm his Vice President. Richard Nixon, the son-of-a-bitch, making George McGovern his Secretary of State. Richard Nixon, the fucking pinko, making Angela Davis his Secretary of Defense. Forty years later, the Brookings Institution honoring Richard Nixon at a ceremony attended by Daniel Ellsberg...

", "

All the other prisoners huddled around the TV were suddenly looking at Gordon. He hadn’t even realized it, but he was laughing. He could hardly contain himself. The looks on the faces around him only made him laugh harder. There was only one path left now. Bursting into song, Gordon sang the anthem he knew best.

"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_15.png"; return construct(0); } // Muskie endings else if (demnomLevel == 1 && watergateconfessLevel == 1 && out == "loss" && quickstats[0] < 270) { e.header = "

A Conversation with Lyn Nofziger and Lee Atwater, January 12th 1975

" e.pages = ["

NOFZIGER: Still beaming from those midterms, Lee?

ATWATER: Hell, Lyn, aren’t you? Maybe this country isn’t finished after all.

NOFZIGER: Church, Bayh, McGovern, Culver, shit even that moron Eagleton. It’s goddamn incredible. All gone. Door’s wide open now. You’re never gonna go one stump speech without hearing a Republican say “who lost Vietnam?” Johnson got us into that damn war, Nixon was bringing peace, and then this moron Muskie stumbles in and loses the whole goddamn country in a year!

", "

ATWATER: You’re right, you’re right. But don’t you think there’s a little more here?

NOFZIGER: What are you getting at?

ATWATER: Well, look at this. You mentioned those Senate races last year, Iowa, Indiana, South Dakota, whatever. They’re all these Midwest states where those liberals got knocked off. But those Democrats…they were never doing all that well there. It was only a matter of time before someone gained a couple of points and beat the sons-of-bitches. Obviously conservatives were gonna do a hell of a lot better in ‘74 than in any year in a long time. So those Senators losing wasn’t anything to write home about. It’s not transformative.

NOFZIGER: Why so dour, Lee?

", "

ATWATER: Dour? Lyn I’m over the goddamn moon! Here, look at this, the races nobody was watching. The ones in the south.

NOFZIGER: They’ve been voting for Democrats since the Civil War. They did it last year and they’ll do it again.

ATWATER: You’re not listening Lyn, look. In Arkansas, Fulbright won, but he did a whole 15 points worse than the last time he was up. That’s a bigger improvement than we saw in South Dakota or Iowa. NOFZIGER: That’s Fulbright, he’s too big of a liberal for them.

", "

ATWATER: Not Talmadge in Georgia. That family’s a damn institution there, nobody would ever knock him down, and nobody gave a rat’s ass about that Senate race. But you know what happened? A goddamn nineteen point swing from the last time he was up! Now do you think that’s because Talmadge suddenly became unpopular overnight down there? Course not. Carolinas, same thing.

NOFZIGER: Christ.

ATWATER: Now nobody was watching these races. All the Democrats I mentioned, all won easily. By a lot too. But the Republicans down there aren’t being drowned by a thousand feet of water anymore. Only a hundred. It’s draining fast. Bussing, the urban liberals, silent majority—

", "

NOFZIGER: I tried that under Nixon and he lost.

ATWATER: But Nixon only lost because he bet wrong with that Watergate shit. Nobody gives a damn about it and he miscalculated. Muskie’s gonna get blown out in ‘76, everyone knows that. But what matters here isn’t just ‘76, it’s ‘80 and ‘84 and ‘88 and ‘92 and all the way to 2000. If you want to craft a real goddamn majority here, it’s gotta run right through the south. It’s changing faster than anyone in Washington realizes, and the next Republican we run has gotta capitalize on that.

NOFZIGER: I don’t buy it. Sounds like bullshit to me."] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_16.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 1 && watergateconfessLevel == 0 && out == "loss" && quickstats[0] < 270) { e.header = "

A Conversation between General Secretary of the Communist Party Andrei Gromyko and Minister for Foreign Affairs Eduard Shevardnadze, 1982

" e.pages = ["

MINISTER SHEVARDNADZE: So you have heard the news from the West?

GENERAL SECRETARY GROMYKO: I have. Nixon was a shrewd political operator. Had he been in power, we might not be facing this current predicament. His understanding of geopolitics was... unique.

MINISTER SHEVARDNADZE: Are you suggesting he would've ignored the operation in Rhodesia?

", "

GENERAL SECRETARY GROMYKO: Not ignored, no. But Nixon understood the importance of the balance of power. He was a realist. He wouldn't have brought the world to the brink of nuclear war over this.

MINISTER SHEVARDNADZE: And Muskie?

GENERAL SECRETARY GROMYKO: Muskie was a moralist. It was his downfall. He saw the world in black and white, good and evil. Such a worldview does not lend itself to effective statecraft.

", "

MINISTER SHEVARDNADZE: And now we have Crane.

GENERAL SECRETARY GROMYKO: Crane... He's an unknown. But if his rhetoric is any indication, he's more Muskie than Nixon. And that concerns me.

MINISTER SHEVARDNADZE: What should we do?

GENERAL SECRETARY GROMYKO: We proceed as planned. Prepare for potential escalation. We've made our move, now it's time to see how the Americans respond.

LEMMON: A former Oscar winner yourself, President Redford, how are you?

REDFORD: Good evening, Jack. I’m doing just well here. We have a wonderful theater here in the White House, and I’ve enjoyed seeing all of the terrific films nominated this year. Oval Office meeting, June 19th 1973

" e.pages = ["

HALDEMAN: The Segretti thing, I think we’ve got to just let that hang—

NIXON: The Muskie letters?

HALDEMAN: Yeah. Because if we start sharply attacking Segretti, incidentally I thought that statement last week was a little too sharp—

NIXON: You do?

", "

HALDEMAN: —because if we start attacking him—

NIXON: Oh I know, the libs and the left-wingers will just totally fall in line to protect him.

HALDEMAN: That’s exactly right.

", "

NIXON: They did it with Hiss, they did it with the Ellsberg thing. [Unintelligible] it again. Jesus Christ.

HALDEMAN: But I think if Ron can deny what Segretti is saying—not the specifics about how the letters said Muskie hated the Candians, and the Irish, and—

NIXON: Fine.

HALDEMAN: —but if Ron can just say the story in The Post is “fundamentally incorrect”—

NIXON: Fundamentally. That’s good. Fine. Use that.

", "

HALDEMAN: The problem isn’t what Segretti did in the primaries. You canceled those projects when Colson brought them to you.

NIXON: That’s right. Because it didn’t make a bit of difference whether it was Muskie, or McGovern, or some dumb fool like Lindsay—

HALDEMAN: Yeah.

NIXON: I really don’t care. They’re all the same.

HALDEMAN: But the attacks after the convention, Colson went further than just feeding some stories to favorable reporters, I mean—

", "

NIXON: No, no, I know Bob. But it’s a dirty business. Nobody comes out clean here.

HALDEMAN: That’s right. But as far as the public goes, I really don’t think these stories are any worse than what some of these Democrats are already making them think—

NIXON: That’s right.

HALDEMAN: In fact I would say it’s a whole lot better. That’s why we should just hang it out.

", "

NIXON: Sure, fine. Get on that—

HALDEMAN: The only wrinkle is there’s one unpublished letter Colson showed me. He didn’t run it, but he just showed it to me.

NIXON: What was it?

HALDEMAN: Well, and remember, this was right before the convention. But Colson showed me this letter he forged it to make it look like this Democratic bigwig was filing it, and it accused Muskie of having a bastard child—

", "

NIXON: Jesus Christ.

HALDEMAN: —sleeping with all sorts of prostitutes, taking acid, and being a homosexual. It was—

NIXON: Well the last part is true, you know.

"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_19.png"; return construct(0); } // CHISHOLM ENDINGS else if (demnomLevel == 2 && watergateconfessLevel == 0 && out == "loss" && quickstats[0] < 270) { e.header = "

Introduction Alternate Nixons

" e.pages = ["

Richard Nixon.

What is it about him? Surely there have been equally corrupt politicians. Elbridge Gerry brought us the gerrymander, Grant ruined reconstruction through graft-and there is no question that Warren G. Harding was America's definition of a corrupt president, at least before 1973... and yet, when one speaks of a Shakespearean figure of self-destruction, when one looks at all the tabloids and all the plays, and all the movies, there is one figure: Richard Nixon.

Probably timing had a lot to do with it. It was the tail-end of the so-called soaring sixties, and America needed someone to make them feel safe, someone to tell them that there's nothing wrong with them, that America's best days were ahead - and he was revealed to be a crook. And then, when everybody had worked out their emotions and rallied behind President Chisholm's promise to get the son-of-a-bitch... he gets shot on the defendant’s stand. Talk about a miscarriage of justice.", "But always coloring the public's ongoing fascination with Richard Nixon is the curiosity (or is it the longing?) for a lost vision of Richard Nixon: What if Dick had won the 1972 election? What if he won the 1960 election? What if he stood for his crimes? What if the good men came and dragged President Tricky from his retirement palace to kick him to death?

Well, when it comes to asking the question What if?, nobody does it better than those who ask it for a living: science fiction writers. I assembled some of the best in the business, along with a few very talented newcomers, and asked them to give me an alternate Nixon story, none of which had ever seen before.", "Here you'll find realistic and powerful pieces such as Barry N. Malzberg's The Pen and the Presidency, bittersweet fantasies like Susan Schwartz's In the Silver Promenade, off-the-wall humor such as Jack Haldeman's Honest Dick's Adventures in Used-Car Sales, futuristic fables such as Laura Resnick's Rhapsody in Blue-Collar, and heart-rending might-have-beens like Nicholas A. DiChario's The Dog in Winter.

When I first agreed to edit this volume, I seriously wondered if there were enough quality Alternate Nixon stories waiting to be told. I should have known better; the men and women who ask What if? for their livelihoods could have filled another dozen such books.

- Mike Resnick", "

WHAT IF...

  • Richard Nixon abandoned politics to pursue an honest living as a used-car salesman? (See Honest Dick's Adventures in Used-Car Sales)
  • The peace activist and Quaker missionary Richard Nixon resorted to more and more extreme action in order to end the war in Southeast Asia? (See A Quaker in Saigon.)
  • The Nixon family were the last true wizards in America, secretly using their powers to shape the country's destiny? (See The Sorcerer of Whittier.)
  • Vice President Nixon received help from an unknown benefactor in order to win the 1960 election... who turned out to be himself!? (See Burglary Among the Stars.)
    • ", "

    In this collection, twenty-five of today's most imaginative science fiction authors reimagine the Nixon saga and create alternate histories that challenge our perceptions of the man and his legacy - tales more intriguing, amusing, and often more poignant than any tabloid can offer."] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_20.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 2 && watergateconfessLevel == 1 && out == "loss" && quickstats[0] < 270) { e.header = "

    Review: Dick and Shirley: A Novel

    " e.pages = ["

    Early in L.R. Hagen’s latest political novel about former Presidents Richard Nixon and Shirley Chisholm, Nixon’s personal secretary watches President Nixon confess on national television to his staff’s misdeeds in the Watergate scandal. The confession, which she views as an “awful sacrifice,” causes her to wonder if maybe her boss will get his own marble temple on National Mall. It’s a gripping moment of naivete, among the many such moments that ground this surprisingly humane dramatization of an era of history that most consider vaudevillian.

    ", "

    In the decades since, the landmarks of the 1970s have become well-known, frequently graffitied pieces of pop culture. The bungling break-in at the Democratic National Headquarters had been recreated and parodied countless times. Americans have been subjected to a series of bad—and often racist—parodies of their first black president by Saturday Night Live. Episodes such as the Nixon Interview, John Tower’s interruption of the State of the Union, the mass pardoning of drug offenders, the failed, Republican-led Chisholm impeachments, the White House Homosexual Rights Rally, and Nixon’s 1982 California Comeback have become ingrained in the public’s psyche. The participants of these episodes have served their time (whether in prison or on television), written their memoirs, and disappeared into oblivion, like so many of the Nixon Tapes.

    ", "

    For a novel to cover these episodes in ways that feel new is no small achievement, though perhaps there is no novelist better suited to the role. Having previously combined political history and fiction in his novels “Dewey Defeats Truman” (2000), “The Unsinkable Jerry Brown” (2005), and “Scoop’s Last War: Memories from Iran” (2012). Hagen is able to capture those frenzied, pre-Worldnet days of the Dictabelt, the Students for Democratic Society, Buddhist Economics, and the San Francisco Riots.

    ", "

    Staying close to the chronology of the 1970s and early 1980s with only a handful of fictional characters, Hagen distinguishes his book from a library of other novels with his inimitable style. Nixon, embittered, complicated, and irascible as ever, serves as one of the major players as does Shirley Chisholm, at once filled with the hopes of a new generation and a crushing knowledge of real life’s disappointments. Also appearing are Nixon’s “ogre” H.R. Haldeman, the creeping Henry Kissenger, preening future presidents Ronald Reagan and Jerry Brown, and an at times exhausting list of the capital’s who’s who. Some Washington area lawyers may be surprised to find constitutional expert Hillary Rodham given not just a passing reference, but an extensive viewpoint chapter that delves into her memories of the Watergate inquiry and as an aide in the Chisholm administration.

    ", "While younger readers and some unfamiliar outsiders may want to keep an eEncyclopedia close by to keep up-to-speed on the more confusing details of the era, “Dick and Shirley” is a page-turner that is at once witty and deeply tragic. Hagen writes with such wit and psychological acuity that many will find themselves sympathizing with characters once thought clown-like or monstrous. Still others will read the book and wonder what might have been had America not treated them with contempt, but genuine empathy and understanding.

    ★★★★½"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_21.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 2 && watergateconfessLevel == 0 && out == "win" && quickstats[0] > 270) { e.header = "

    50 Years Later, a Changed America Grapples With Its Darkest Days

    " e.pages = ["The New York Times is committed to providing readers with insightful, independent reporting. In accordance with Section 389 of the Decency in Communications Act of 1981, we are required to inform readers that the following article may contain content that some find graphic, disturbing, or emotionally harmful. A more detailed rating advisory for parents and educators can be found here.

    ", "

    WASHINGTON, DC—When President Richard Nixon delivered his final address to the nation on November 17, 1973, most cameras did not focus on the man standing on the far edge of the platform, Mike Endicott. A long-time member of the Secret Service, Endicott considered his presence on that day to be a footnote, purely to keep any “kooks” and “weirdos”—as he called them—from the president as he defended himself against allegations of impropriety over the alleged break-in at the Watergate Hotel in Washington, DC.

    ", "

    Today, Endicott, 79, spends most of his days wondering if he should have paid less attention to the crowd and closer attention to the man giving the speech.

    “He was standing right there,” said Mr. Endicott, pointing at a discrete “X” in the Ballroom of the Americas at the Walt Disney World Resort in Orlando, Florida. He and his grandson had been invited as part of a 50th anniversary memorial service. “He looked so tired when he got off the stage, but he was always tired in those days. I wish I had said something. It still hurts to remember.

    ", "

    In Washington, the surviving principals of the Administration and its scandals offered similar reflections.

    “A sad day,” former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger said when reached by dmail.

    “The unfortunate result of an ill-gotten presidency,” said former Nixon White House Counsel John Dean.

    ", "

    A Different Time

    For many older Americans, the days leading up to President Nixon’s death have inspired not morbid interest, as the Kennedy Assassination does, but pain. Even fictionalized portrayals of the former president—most notably Oliver Stone’s 1992 made-for-television movie Nixon—have sparked protests and outcry.

    ", "

    Still, the contours of the story are well-known. As revealed on later-recovered tapes, a much closer-than expected race against the young, black Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm sent the president spiraling. Leaks, congressional investigations into the Watergate break-in, the resignation of his vice president, family discord, and a growing list of indictments against key aides led to a further deterioration of the president’s mental state. By November 1973—with the collapse of the Paris Peace Accords and Israel’s use of nuclear weapons amid the Second Arab-Israeli War—most mainstream historians describe a president “unmoored,” frequently drunk or depressed and unable to respond to crises.

    ", "

    Much of this would go unnoticed by the public until the morning of Nov. 23, 1973, when newly sworn-in president Carl Albert informed a shocked public that President Nixon had taken his life in the White House the prior evening. His remarks and the revelations that followed the Berger Commission’s investigations into the death, would lead to an uncomfortable reckoning with the Nixon Administration’s extensive criminality, the toll of public office on high-ranking officials, and the state of American mental health care.

    “I don’t think any of us could have expected it at the time. I mean, we just didn’t have those kinds of conversations back then,” offered Elizabeth Drew, one of the leading chroniclers of the Watergate scandal. “It’s hard to explain what it was like to young people.”

    ", "Somber Reflections

    While a handful of conservative activists—chief among them Pat Buchanan and Roger Stone—continue to allege a lurid conspiracy by the CIA and disgruntled federal workers to kill the president, recent polls suggest Americans are ready to move on.

    One recent miniphone survey of American adults by the Pew Research Center found that some 83% of all adults accept the Berger Commission’s findings and convictions against the Watergate suspects. Less than 6% of Americans agree with theories that President Ted Kennedy was involved in the president’s passing—a number that could reflect Kennedy’s historically high approval ratings during his two terms and continued praise by mainstream historians for his “politics of empathy.”", "

    The survey further noted about 64% of Americans support the National Mental Health Service, a landmark program pioneered by the Ted Kennedy Administration. One in five adults are believed to receive mental health support through the NMHS, NHS, or a private plan.

    In places like New York City, however, the focus was less on political battles of yesteryear and more on the man at the center of the tragedy.

    ", "

    “We must change those things that we can and accept that which we cannot,” said former Vice President and First Lady Elizabeth Dole at an international vigil in New York for those suffering untreated conditions. “Whether you’re man or woman, Republican or Democrat, American or Soviet, let us continue to fight for a kinder, gentler world.”

    It was the one-time president’s daughter Julie who got the last word, though. In an emotional speech, where she often seemed on the verge of tears, the 75-year-old told the crowd, “I wish I’d known what my father was going through. I wish I could go back and tell him that it would all be alright, that no matter what he or his staff did, we could get through this together.”

    ", "

    “Daddy, wherever you are, I love you.” She continued. “I hope you know I’ll never stop loving you.”"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_22.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 2 && watergateconfessLevel == 1 && out == "win" && quickstats[0] > 270) { e.header = "

    The Bicentennial Bloodshed: 25 Years Later - Blog post

    " e.pages = ["Will anyone ever remember where the Underground Liberation Movement came from? Its inspiration taken from the Tupamaros in Uruguay? Its members largely young 20-somethings disillusioned with politics after the whole-hearted embrace of Richard Nixon and demolition of the Chisholm campaign? Or God forbid, what its ideology was. Even its members couldn’t have told you that. What anyone who was alive for the Bicentennial will be able to tell you is what it looked like when the ULM’s leader’s brains were splattered across Howard K. Smith and his new suit.

    There is no stunt more publicity-seeking than kidnapping the President of the United States on the Fourth of July live on television, and ULM learned from the best. Vietnam was called the first “TV war”, so why wouldn’t the urban guerillas rebelling against the war at home use some of the same tactics? How many search and destroy missions were beamed into American living rooms, turning the massacres of Vietnamese farmers into a spectacle for little Timmy to watch while eating cold chicken before flipping channels to What’s My Line?

    ", "

    The Bicentennial Massacre was an inevitable response to the American consumerism those young kids in the ULM had been raised on. They may have been trying to rebel against it, but the same corporations the ULM was targeting turned the Bicentennial Massacre into its biggest success. Richard Nixon getting tackled by SWAT team members blowing away acne-scarred white college kids got more live viewers than the Moon Landing, and why wouldn’t it? The next forty years speak for themselves. TV hijackings were once unthinkable, but now they’re on every Thursday night. God only knows what today’s generation being radicalized with TV dinners today will do next."] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_23.png"; return construct(0); } // KENNEDY ENDINGS else if (demnomLevel == 3 && out == "loss" && quickstats[0] == 0) { e.header = "

    Weeping and gnashing of teeth

    " e.pages = ["

    It was a night of grandeur and opulence, the kind Richard Nixon had always dreamed of. The chandeliers glittered like a thousand suns, the champagne flowed like the Potomac, and the guests – oh, the guests! They were the crème de la crème of high society, the veritable titans of American culture.

    Among the first to arrive was the elegant and always stylish Jacqueline Kennedy, her pearls glinting in the soft light. Dick smirked, Jackie, what a surprise. Didn't expect to see you here. What was she doing here?

    As the night rolled on, the guest list grew more peculiar. The late-night arrival of Ted Kennedy was a shock, to say the least. Ted, you old dog, Dick grumbled, Crashing my party. You're off the guest list for the next one. But Teddy just laughed, a booming, hearty laugh that seemed to echo forever in the grand ballroom.

    ", "

    The parade of arrivals continued with John Jr., a figure Dick always found himself consciously avoiding. Then came Sargent Shriver, and then…

    And then, as if the world had gone mad, a procession of Kennedys poured in, one after the other, each arrival more startling than the last. Eunice, Patricia, Robert Jr., even the old patriarch, Joe, they all sauntered in, each one grinning like the Cheshire Cat. Dick's head spun. It was a Kennedy jamboree, a veritable Camelot reunion, here in his grand gala.

    But then, the impossible happened. Through the grand entrance walked Robert F. Kennedy, his famous smile lighting up the room. A hush fell over the party-goers. Bobby, Dick stammered, How...?

    And before he could regain his composure, Jack Kennedy joined the party, looking as young as the day he died. The sight of the two brothers was overwhelming. Dick's simmering rage erupted. What is this? Some sort of sick joke? His voice thundered through the grand hall.

    ", "But his guests just laughed, a high, deafening laugh that echoed through the grand hall. The Kennedys, all of them, laughing, toasting, celebrating. Dick was left standing alone at his own grand gala.

    He tried to run, to escape the mocking laughter and the sickening sight of the Kennedys. But the doors were locked, the windows barred. The laughter grew louder, the room hotter. The grand chandeliers seemed to burn with an intense heat, the champagne turned to fire in his throat.

    And then, he understood. The grand gala, the Kennedys, the locked doors – the heat, the fire, the laughter. This was no earthly gala. As the realization dawned on Dick, the Kennedys, in unison, raised their champagne glasses. To Richard, they chorused, their voices fading into the fiery abyss. Welcome to eternity."] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_24.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 3 && out == "loss" && quickstats[0] < 151) { e.header = "

    Mr Henry Kissinger, born on 27 May 1923, former United States National Security Advisor, is allegedly responsible for the crime of genocide and crimes against humanity directed against civilian populations (under articles 6(c) and 8(2)(b)(ii)(v) of the Rome Statute) in the Lao People's Democratic Republic, People's Republic of Kampuchea, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.     Goddamn, it’s stuffy in here

    " e.pages = ["

    Dick couldn’t understand why anyone would bother to have a funeral in the sweltering heat in a church like this. As a matter of fact, why was he here? Dick looked around. Not a distinctive face in the crowd. They were all a blur. The church though, it looked ornate. It’s a shame Dick couldn’t remember whose funeral this was. Must be somebody important. The dull bastard giving this eulogy was droning on and on. Maybe some Washington up-and-comer trying to make a name for himself. “Smug son-of-a-bitch”, Dick thought to himself.

    ", "

    Then it was Ted again. He had grown twice in size, his shock of hair had turned pure white, and his voice, though aged, boomed even louder, rattling Dick’s skull.

    ", "...and, of course, I’d like to thank my successors, President Kennedy, President Kennedy, and President Kennedy, for being here today…” Trying to get up, Dick hit his head on something hard.     MAN TWO: Well, eh-heh, I’d sure hope so. I’d be the president, after all.

    MAN ONE: Yes, yes. Absolutely. You need complete control. But let’s not put the cart before the horse. You’re right that this country can’t afford another for years of that, that cocksucker.     MAN ONE: Don’t you pull that—", "

    MAN TWO: Well,

    MAN ONE: You don’t know what it’s like! My only mistake, ever, was being too nice to those [EXPLETIVE DELETED] [EXPLETIVE DELETED] [EXPLETIVE DELETED] sacks of [EXPLETIVE DELETED] [EXPLETIVE DELETED]. I didn’t—I’ve never even lost. Not the first time. You know that.

    ", "

    MAN ONE: Right, right. And the people on your side, my God. They give me so much shit for ‘72. But they don’t look! That was a damn close thing! If I just didn’t make that damn fool mistake…it was a lapse in judgment. Playing into their games.

    MAN TWO: Well, I’m sure you’re right. But to me, and my people, when we think about this, we think about this story, about a man, in Soviet Russia, trying to buy a car. He goes up to the owner and asks for a car, to which the owner responds: 'You know there is a 10 year waiting list?' The man then answers, 'OK,' and after some time he then agrees to buy a car. So he pays for the car in advance, and just before he leaves he asks the owner, 'Can I pick the car up in the morning or afternoon?' And the owner says, 'It's 10 years away, what difference does it make?' And the man says, 'The plumber is coming in the morning'.

    ", "

    MAN ONE: …

    MAN TWO: Well, you’re the owner, right? And the voters, the Republican Party, they’re the man. And the most important thing is that you can get a new model, so you don’t spend another ten years driving an old car. So, uhhh, well, we all appreciate your service. We all do.     PRESIDENT: Good afternoon. I want to talk today about what an exciting week this has been, and how historic this moment is. I think I am the only elected official to meet with Fidel Castro, while elected. He had the most unique handshake I’ve ever shook, and I’ve shook a lot. He wound up—

    PRESIDENT CASTRO: [inaudible]

    PRESIDENT: —and thrust his hand down [motioning hand down]. I call him Mr. President, because they have elections too, y’know. He’s the only one on the ballot, and in America we give you two. Oh boy, one more than Cuba.

    ", "

    " e.pages = ["

    Good afternoon, everyone. We are here today to mourn a patriot. A fighter. An American. A President. Like all of you, I’d like to express my heartfelt sympathies to the Nixon family, which, in a way, includes all of us. I’d also like to thank State President Botha for taking the time to be with us today. Your cause is our cause, too, and I’m sure if the President were still with us, he’d be standing with you and against the naive and reckless actions of the current administration as it stands for your country.

    But while acknowledging those with us today, I think it’s also worth taking a moment to acknowledge two men who are conspicuously absent. Never before have sitting or former Presidents declined to attend the funeral of one of their predecessors.     Presidential Address to the Nation, January 28, 1981

    " e.pages = ["

    The president was on television. The president was on every television. Their arsenic white outfit and the dark shades of the Oval Office cast strange colors into darkened living rooms across the country.

    “My fellow Americans, the last four years have seen no shortage of crises—the wanton criminality of prior Administrations, expensive debacles in foreign policy, the destruction of our cities by lawless urban elements. As they look out at the rusted factories, at mothers trapped in poverty, at an educational system that serves only elite interests, many have questioned whether our country is capable of facing the challenges ahead.”

    ", "

    There was a pause. A theatrical gesture. “I am here today to tell you that our long, national nightmare is over. No longer will American policy be dictated by the parochial interests of well-financed New York kingmakers, but by you. Already, I have ordered my staff to begin looking at ways to rid the federal bureaucracy of those agents and provocateurs who wish to inflict further carnage through social engineering. Already, I have issued an executive order to begin dismantling the Department of Education and end the child indoctrination that flourished under feckless, liberal leaders like Richard Nixon and John Lindsay.”

    ", "

    Millions stared, transfixed by the president’s well-groomed face. “This work will not be easy, but I promise that we will end the war against the God-given values on which our nation was founded. Like Ronald Reagan before he was viciously slain by Democrat Party radicals, I will fight until my dying breath to rid this country of criminality and restore us to the values on which we were founded. We will banish the night and bring forth the dawn.”

    Phyllis Schlafly, President of the United States, folded her hands and stared directly into dozens of cameras before her. She gave a smile that revealed many teeth.

    “It’s morning again, America. I hope you’re ready.”

    Report of the President’s Commission on Abuses of Power Under the Nixon Administration, January 27, 1977

    " e.pages = ["Chief Justice Warren Burger, Chairman

    PRESIDENT JOHN LINDSAY, by Executive Order 11705 dated March 6, 1973, created this Commission to investigate the abuses of power occurring under President Richard M. Nixon, from 1969 to 1973. President Lindsay directed the Commission to evaluate all the facts and circumstances surrounding the Watergate break-in, its subsequent cover-up, any further abuses connected to the break-in, and to report its findings and conclusions to him.

    The subject of the Commission's inquiry was an event which confused the public. The break-in at the Watergate hotel on June 17, 1972, produced many theories and wild rumors in the press.", "

    After President Nixon’s election defeat and his denial of all guilt, public attention focused both on the extent of the evidence against him and the possibility of a cover-up. President Nixon’s subsequent retreat from public life heightened public interest and stimulated additional suspicions and rumors.In the United States and abroad, this event demanded an explanation.

    ", "

    Issuing its final report on January 27, 1977, the Commission stresses that its work is not yet complete. A full accounting of the facts surrounding the Watergate break-in may never be known. We have heard from up to 2,000 witnesses, ranging from thieves to presidents, and have never gotten the same answer about the motive for the break-in from any of them. As Chief Justice of the Supreme Court and Chairman of this Presidential Commission, I urge PRESIDENT RONALD REAGAN to reconsider his decision to end the Commission’s work before it is complete.

    "] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_32.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 4 && out == "win" && quickstats[0] < 326) { e.header = "

    Press Conference Given by the Press Secretary, July 3rd, 1993

    " e.pages = ["

    George Stephanopoulos (GS):Uh, good morning, everybody. We’ve got a lot on the agenda today, so let’s begin. At noon today the President will meet with President Jiang via teleconference, and the purpose of this meeting is going to be to discuss recent North Korean military exercises near the demilitarized zone. At 2 PM he will meet with members of the Congressional Black Caucus in order to discuss his urban renewal plan, and at 4 PM he will host a reception for the winners of the Presidential Medal of Freedom. And at 6 PM, he will have a private dinner with his wife, Bess, to celebrate their 10-year anniversary. Now I’m here to take your questions for today. Please raise your hand if you have a question.

    ", "

    Reporter 1: Mr. Stephanopoulos, the latest polls show that President Koch’s approval rating has dropped to an all-time low of 25%. Many Americans are dissatisfied with his urban renewal policies, which his critics have said have failed to revitalize the inner cities and have instead increased crime, poverty, and racial tensions. How does the President plan to address these issues?

    ", "

    GS: Thank you for your question.

    The President is well aware of the challenges facing our urban areas and is committed to investing in infrastructure, education, health care, and public safety for all Americans, regardless of where they live. If you'll remember, he recently proposed his urban renewal agenda to Congress, where the administration is confident we have the votes to get relief to our cities.

    ", "

    Reporter 2: Mr. Stephanopoulos, another source of controversy for the President is his personal life. As you know, he has been accused of having a homosexual affair with his former aide, Daniel Harrison, I believe, who recently published a tell-all book about their relationship. The book claims that the President lied about his sexual orientation and used his power to cover up his scandal. How does the President respond to these allegations?

    ", "

    GS: Thank you for your question. The President has made it clear that he is not going to dignify these baseless and malicious accusations with a response. He has always been honest and transparent with the American people about who he is and what he stands for, and as you all know, he's been married to his wife Bess for 10 years today, and they have a loving and supportive relationship. He is focused on doing his job as the President of the United States and serving the best interests of the-

    Reporter 3: Mr. Stephanopoulos, I'm sorry to interrupt, but I have just received news that former President Nixon has died at the age of 80. He was hospitalized last week after suffering a stroke. Do you have any comment on this news?

    ", "

    GS: I’m sorry to hear that, I was not aware of this news until you just informed me. President Nixon was a great leader who shaped America as we knew it and will be missed dearly. He had a long and distinguished career in public service, both as a congressman, a senator, a vice president, and a president. I’m sure the President is saddened by the news of his passing and will extend his condolences to his family and friends. The President will certainly be attending the funeral service to pay his respects and honor his legacy.
