    February 14th, 1973

    " e.pages = ["

    “Woodward, what did Deep Throat tell you? Did he say anything about Kalmbach or the Italian Letter?”

    “What time is it?”

    “Were you asleep? It’s past 3 A.M!”

    “Shit!”

    Sprinting down the basement corridor, Woodward hailed a cab moving away from his new apartment in Southwest Washington. Stopping three quarters of a mile outside the meeting spot, Woodward only had a $20 bill and the driver was out of change. Woodward angrily told him to keep the money and hurriedly walked the rest of the distance.", "

    Arriving at the designated location out of breath, Woodward noticed the flicker of Deep Throat’s lighter across the garage.

    “Were you followed?”

    Deep Throat’s leathery skin already made him look worn, but Woodward thought he looked like he hadn’t slept in a week. This meeting needed to be quick.

    “No. We know about Segretti…the Italian letter that lost Lindsay all his support there, making it look like he said that slur…we have pieces, but we can’t figure out what the puzzle is supposed to look like.”

    Taking a puff from his cigarette, Deep Throat smirked.

    ", "

    They always wanted Lindsay. Everyone at FBI, even Gray, knows that that was the goal of all the…what did you call it...ratfucking?

    “Was Watergate a part of this?”

    “I can’t tell you that.”

    “Alright…look, we know Hunt was checking books out on the hardhat riots, and the violence at Lindsay’s rallies…we know that. Segretti says Kalmbach handled funds that went towards some of the agitators.”

    ", "

    “That’s good. You need to work from the outer edges. Segretti, Kalmbach, those are the type of men meant to be disposable. They can be leaned on. But there’s no doubt. Colson and Mitchell were behind the ratfucking operation. The stink bombs in Humphrey’s headquarters, the clashes at Wallace’s rallies in Miami, the…what was it, forged letters that made it look like Lindsay called the Irish-”

    “You mean the Italian letter?”

    “No, get out your notebook, there’s more.”

    "] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_34.png"; return construct(0); } // HUMPHREY ENDINGS else if (demnomLevel == 5 && out == "loss" && watergateconfessLevel == 1) { e.header = "

    Abstract

    " e.pages = ["In recent years, one of the biggest topics of discussion in the political science community has been the ‘American Exception’ to the global trend of decreasing trust in government. Eurocommunist parties have surged at the expense of traditional parties across the EU, even forming a majority government in Italy. Popular rebellions have led to the collapse of long-established governments across the third world, from the Philippines to South Korea to South Africa. Even the popularity of Premier Jiang Qing has supposedly been slipping. But, in spite of it all, polling has indicated that upwards of 60% of the public has registered trust in their government to ‘do the right thing’ always or most of the time, similar to the numbers seen during the Kennedy and Eisenhower administrations, with the policies to match.

    ", "

    What accounts for the American public being seemingly frozen in time? Established political science literature from the historicist school points to two discrete moments: President Nixon’s ‘confession’ during the 1972 election, and President Humphrey’s resignation due to failing health in early 1976. These moments, as the story goes, were brave, heroic acts of great moral character that showed Americans that even those with everything on the line will put the good of the country first. Other factors, like the resolute leadership shown by President Jackson during the South American Crisis, are said to have contributed to this, too, but the upshot is still the same: a defining characteristic of modern American political culture derives solely from historical contingency.

    ", "

    As we work to make political science into a more rigorous, scientifically legitimate discipline, I believe that it is ideas like this that we must fight against first and foremost. The influence of the historicists is strong, but, like the insurgents who fought against Torrijos and Allende to maintain the status quo in their Canal, we must never give up, even against insurmountable odds. In this article, I posit that the high level of public trust among the American public is not a result of mere chance, but is in fact the logical outcome of the structure of American institutions. Through the decision-making structure created by checks and balances, a weak two-party system, and a strong, state-based upper house, American politicians are given powerful incentives to act with good behavior. Practically, as we continue the Global Restructuring programme, this understanding of the strengths of our system should influence how we redesign rouge governments following police actions.

    The Institutional Foundations of Public Trust, Terry M. Moe, 1990"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_35.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 5 && out == "loss" && watergateconfessLevel == 0) { e.header = "

    Barbara Walters interviewing President Hayden and First Lady Fonda, on ABC News’ 20/20, October 18th, 1991

    " e.pages = ["

    Barbara Walters: And how much did that visit influence your whole outlook on the war?

    First Lady Fonda: Oh, totally. Completely. It was one of the most, you know, surreal experiences that I-I’ve ever had. Looking up, as an American, and seeing bombs with my country’s flag on them fall over my head, it, it was a life-changing experience.

    ", "

    President Hayden: And, like millions of Americans, it informed our firm conviction against the use of force in Angola and Mozambique, to prop up an apartheid regime in South Africa waging war under

    Reagan. Which is why I wanted to focus on running for office while Jane thought differently. I mean, when we went to Cabo Delgado in ‘78—

    ", "

    Walters: Let’s return to 1972 though, to happier times, before your separation. Tom, that’s when you first ran for president, as a third party candidate earning hardly any support—

    Hayden: Well I wouldn’t—

    Walters: and it was because you were upset about Hubert Humphrey getting the nomination again. Did that campaign set you on today’s course to the Oval Office?

    ", "

    Hayden: Look, we were against the war, and I had been on the receiving end of what a Humphrey presidency would be like in Chicago years earlier. I don’t care whether the club cracking my skull is wielded by a liberal or a conservative, the point is to stob the beating. Which is why I pushed back forcefully, even against President Mondale for his aggression towards Grenada—

    Walters: I-I’m sorry Mr. President, I have to cut you off. ABC News has just reported five minutes ago that former President Richard Nixon passed away, reportedly due to a stroke. What are your first comments on that?

    ", "

    Hayden: I’m sorry, when was this?

    Walters: The report is from five minutes—<

    Hayden: But did he pass away this morning or—

    Walters: I—uh, we don’t know—

    ", "

    Hayden: Okay. Well, President Nixon, he was obviously—well, let me start over. I know we all have strong feelings on the trial—even today—I mean, Humphrey pardoning that…look, it’s what motivated me to run for Senate in the first place, I was so….anyway, I’m sorry. Uh, look, what his administration did i-in Cambodia, when you look at what’s happening there today. I mean, they’re still trying to recover, you know? From well, the bombings obviously, but also from the genocide, which he set the groundwork for.", "So, when I think of President Nixon, I guess, well—I mean he was president in a momentous time. He, I suppose, did what was expected of him. I don’t think he brought the country together or anything, but—well, when you look at what was happening before, with the war, the—you know, the riots…it was already happening before he took office. I guess…he did what was expected of him.

    Walters: First Lady Fonda, your thoughts?

    ", "

    Fonda: Richard Nixon was a scumbag and a crook."] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_36.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 5 && out == "win") { e.header = "

    Chapter Five. Helsinki, 1987

    " e.pages = ["It was a cold winter morning when I made it to Finlandia Hall. My plane had only touched down a day prior. But I could not dawdle, as I had been granted a rare opportunity to interview the retired Soviet leader, Leonid Brezhnev, in private. The meeting was scheduled ahead of the meeting between Chairman Yanayev and President Rodino. As I made my way to the elegant room where Brezhnev was staying, I couldn't help but feel both excitement and fear. The chance to speak with a figure of such historical significance in only my second year as a journalist was an honor.

    As I entered the hotel suite, I was met with a sight that I will never forget. The once-powerful leader now appeared frail, leaning on a cane for support. His health had forced him into retirement in 1980, and while he had been on the mend, the toll of the years was evident. He greeted me with a warm smile.

    Ms. Palin, it is a pleasure to meet you, Brezhnev said, his voice tinged with withering. Please, have a seat.

    ", "

    I settled into the chair across from him, nervous yet eager to begin the interview. We discussed various political matters, including the changes in the Soviet Union and the delicate state of international affairs. Brezhnev spoke slowly, as if pained by the simple motion of conversation.. Throughout our chat, I noticed his mind occasionally drifting, as if memories of his time in power were resurfacing. He spoke fondly of his time as the General Secretary of the Communist Party and leader of the Soviet Union.

    After delving into his tenure as General Secretary, I decided it was time to share the news of Richard Nixon's passing.

    ", "

    Mr. Brezhnev, there is something I must tell you, I said gently, I am not sure if you are aware, but Richard Nixon passed away yesterday.

    I see, Brezhnev replied solemnly, his voice softening. It's a sad day indeed.

    The room fell into a contemplative silence. Brezhnev gazed out of the window, his eyes fixed on the snow blanketed of Helsinki below.", "

    I couldn't help but wonder if I had seen tears glistening in his eyes. But even years after, I'm unsure.

    After a moment of nothing, we finally continued. We spoke of his retirement, the state of the Soviet Union, and his hopes for the future. After about thirty minutes had concluded, I left the room. I did not see Brezhnev for the rest of the day, and heard that a month later, he had passed away.

    Going Rogue - A Life In Journalism, 2009. Pg. 128. Sarah L. Palin

    "] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_37.png"; return construct(0); } // JACKSON ENDINGS else if (demnomLevel == 6 && out == "loss") { e.header = "

    CBS Evening News. Conversation between Chief of Staff Harry Haldeman and Walter Cronkite, April 15th, 1979.

    " e.pages = ["

    Cronkite: And that was former Chief of Staff Harry Haldeman with his new book ‘The Ends of Power: My time with President Nixon’. Thanks for coming on, Harry.

    [Camera pans over to Haldeman, smiling, holding a book which has a picture of him and Nixon as the cover.]

    Haldeman: It’s my pleasure, Walter. President Nixon was a remarkable man. It pains me so much that our nation not only lost one of the, in my opinion, best Presidents in recent memory, but I myself lost a frien–

    [Haldeman is suddenly shushed as Cronkite diverts his attention to his earpiece.]

    ", "

    Cronkite: I’m sorry to interrupt you Harry. If you’ve just tuned in, President Jackson has gone live in Washington, and is addressing the nation.

    [Camera cuts to a hastily set up office, American flag and globe in the back. In the center is President Jackson. He looks withered. Sick.]

    Jackson: My fellow citizens, at this hour, American forces are in the stages of conducting military operations to cease Chinese infringement upon Taiwanese, American and Vietnamese waters. As you are all aware, tensions have escalated as the Chinese government has dispatched nuclear submarines into the waters near Taiwan. These actions pose a grave threat to the stability and peace in the region.

    ", "

    Our objective is clear - to protect the sovereignty of our Asian allies, uphold the principles of international law, and prevent any further escalation of hostilities. We undertake this operation with the utmost care and consideration for the lives involved. Our priority is to avoid escalation while sending a strong and clear message to those who infringe upon America and her allies.

    ", "

    I want to be clear in my message to Chairwoman Jiang Qing. We have always sought peaceful and constructive dialogue with China, and we continue to do so. The United States remains steadfast in its support for democracy and freedom around the world, and we will not waver in the face of threats.

    God bless you all, and may God bless the United States of America.

    [The broadcast ends just as General Singlaub walks into frame and aides quickly begin gathering papers.]"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_38.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 6 && out == "win") { e.header = "

    Freedom in the World, 1988-1989. Pp. 476-477.

    " e.pages = ["

    United States of America

    Economy: Capitalist

    Polity: Decentralized dominant-party

    Population: 245,000,000

    ", "

    Political Rights: 4

    Civil Liberties: 5

    Freedom Rating: 9

    An ethnically complex state with minor territorial subnationalities

    ", "Political Rights. The United States is a constitutional democracy with three separate centers of power:a weak congress and judiciary and a dominant president. Elections are regulated at the local level and greatly vary in fairness and competitiveness state-by-state. While historically characterized by a competitive two-party system, American politics since the mid-1970s has devolved to a dominant-party democracy, led by the Democratic Party and its dominant Wallace clique. Democrats have continuously held control over all three elected branches of the federal government since the 1972 election and have held de facto control of the unelected judiciary system since the 1977 mass impeachments that followed Operation Car Wash.", "Opposition to the party remains weak following the court’s decision in United States v. Liddy to classify the opposition Republican Party as a criminal organization. Some have pointed to localized success by so-called ‘spring-up’ parties, such as Solidarity USA in Chicago, Homeowners for Ecology in the affluent south and southwest, and the Family Farmer Revolutionary Front in the rural midwest as evidence of a thaw in party control, but newly-announced national security guidelines stand to hinder the continued viability and legal standing of such groups.

    ", "

    Civil Liberties. While freedom of speech and the press is enshrined in the constitution, the arrest and execution of former Representative Richard Nixon (Presidential, Vice Presidential and Senatorial titles legally expunged in United States v. Chen) following the conclusion of Operation Car Wash has been described as creating a freezing effect on acts of public opposition generally. The press is private, but restricted. Political reporting in particular has been curtailed in both size and scope following the court’s decision in Los Angeles Times v. AFSCME to overturn The New York Times Co. v. Sullivan. Many major press outlets have come under the majority control of newly-organized financial groups with ties to organizations (First Alabama Bancshares, Southern Company, the Coca-Cola Company, etc.) that see substantial subsidies from the Wallace government. While most pre-Wallace civil liberties are enshrined in law, the precedent set by the 1979 repeal of the 22nd amendment has vastly decreased their credibility.", "Civil rights protections for protected classes are regularly unenforced, with representation for minorities limited to administration-supporting ‘token’ representatives. The government rarely loses in the courts. Unions are politically influential. Although a relatively capitalistic country, the combination of tax loads and the decisive government role in agriculture, energy, defense, and other industries restricts individual choice.

    Comparatively: The United States is as free as Singapore, less free than Mexico, freer than Nicaragua.

    President George Wallace: 1973-"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_40.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 7 && out == "loss" && watergateconfessLevel == 1) { e.header = "

    Eulogy by former Governor and Secretary of Housing and Urban Development George Romney at the funeral of President Nixon, January 29th 1993

    " e.pages = ["

    I didn’t exactly hope or expect to be back in D.C. so soon after the inauguration - certainly not for… an event like this - today, we mark the passing of a great man… a man I could call a friend, a mentor, one time opponent…

    Him and I - we had a similar path through life. We both grew up in desperate poverty, we both forged our own paths through life - he, through the armed services, and me, through bringing the positive force of business - and labor - and harnessing… that so that we could end the tyranny in Nazi Europe…", "

    President Nixon was many things, to many people - yet he remained a man who always acted in service of the American people, irrespective of the political consequences, irrespective of the fate of his own career. That - that is a quality many hope to aspire to, yet fail to do so. President Nixon did not fail.

    He faced many trials, many grave dangers and trials… which - he maneuvered America through, he did. And let me say this - I am glad he was the man in the White House during those troubles, I can gladly say I am. Some would say that… had he been there for just another 4 years, the course of the nation would have been changed for the better - much better, had a certain man not succeeded…

    I… I apologize if I am rambling - I hope you can forgive me.

    [Bats eyes]", "President Nixon was a patriot, he was an American hero, and I hope future Presidents - and citizens… strive to emulate him. I would like to thank my son, President Romney, for allowing myself to give this brief eulogy in his stead. And - I would also like to thank President Percy, President Stevenson, Prime Minister Steel, and Premier Yeltsin for being here today… Thank you, and God Bless you all."] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_41.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 7 && out == "win" && watergateconfessLevel == 0 && quickstats[0] < 325) { e.header = "

    Remarks by The President in a Press Conference, Washington, D.C., April 19 1993

    " e.pages = ["THE PRESIDENT: Well, uhh, good afternoon at the Hill, everyone. I meant to talk to you today about the regulatory relief bill we’re working on, and I’m sure we’ll get to that eventually. But I’m also sure you’ve all heard the news by now, so I have some remarks before we get into things.

    So, first, my condolences to the Nixon family for their loss. I hope everyone will respect their privacy during this time of mourning. And I think it’s important that every American remember that respect for the office, the Presidency, is something that will always be at the core of our nation’s values. It’s something I talked a lot about during the campaign, and it’s something the past administrations have focused on, too, over the past, uhhh, period. And I think that’s important. You have a question?

    ", "

    REPORTER: Mr. President, will you be going to the funeral?

    THE PRESIDENT: Well, Mark, as you know, we have a busy week ahead of us. I still plan on meeting Chairman Kryuchkov, and that’s not the sort of thing that takes, you know, just one or two days. So I don’t want to pressure the family to move things on our schedule. As for President Jackson and President Wallace, I can’t speak for them, of course. But, look, it was a tough period for our history.", "I’ve played my part, ever since President Wallace gave me the Chennault case. We’ve all played our part in some way, really. But you always have to move forward. That’s what I’m about, that’s what this administration is about. And I think that’s what this country is about.

    Now, about the bill…

    - President Richard Shelby, 1993-2001"] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_42.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 7 && out == "win" && watergateconfessLevel == 1 && quickstats[0] < 325) { e.header = "

    The Assassination of Richard Nixon: A Marked Man by Liberty Watch Press, 1979

    " e.pages = ["

    On February 22nd, 1974, the day Samuel Byck boarded Delta Airlines flight 523, Richard Nixon’s presidency was under siege. Some will say his presidency was doomed from the start, but Nixon’s problems really began with his televised Oval Office statement on September 19th, 1972, just four days after Gordon Liddy and CIA agent Howard Hunt were indicted. The establishment press called Nixon’s speech a confession, trying to link the president to the sordid Watergate break-in, but that couldn’t have been further from the truth. President Nixon was trying to warn the public that he was under assault, from forces far beyond any elected official, and too few of us listened.

    ", "

    To any keen observer of the black arts of the national security state, the entire break-in reeked of a set-up. CIA agents Howard Hunt and James McCord were embedded in the White House and the president’s re-election campaign, like moles in a foreign intelligence agency, rigging the whole thing to blow. They were caught at Watergate at once, something no CIA agent would ever be stupid enough to do. But why? Why would the CIA, the entire political establishment, and the media all want to take down Richard Nixon? Because he was a threat. They started wars, and he ended them. The corporate Democrats punished Nixon in July 1972 for trying to end the war in Vietnam, and nominated extreme hawk George Wallace.

    ", "

    By all accounts, the Watergate affair should have tarred Nixon forever, dooming his re-election campaign, ending the SALT treaties and detente with the Soviet Union. But there was one thing this deep state didn’t account for: Richard Nixon himself. By taking the honorable road, and leveling with the American people in a way that liar Johnson never did, Nixon exposed the machinations of the deep state. They would never forgive him for it.

    ", "

    When Byck flew that jet into the White House, he wasn’t just a lone nut assassinating the president. He was a patsy in an intelligence operation far beyond his control. With his V.P. gone two days earlier, and no announcement of who Nixon would pick next, Carl Albert became president. A notorious drunk, Albert was the type of dope the deep state could control. Nixon’s honorable peace in Vietnam collapsed, leading to the domination of South East Asia by communist forces. Richard Nixon had ended our wars, and he paid a terrible punishment for it. Let us not repeat the same mistake in 1980. If you want peace, vote Buchanan!

    ", "

    More by Liberty Watch Press:

    Church and State: Behind the President Who Destroyed Our Intelligence Agencies

    Red Flag Over Tehran: The Marxist-Islamic Movement Taking Over the Middle East

    Shooting Up America: The Red Chinese Heroin Infecting Our Cities

    "] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_43.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 7 && out == "win" && watergateconfessLevel == 0 && quickstats[0] > 324) { e.header = "

    THE NIXON ‘CURSE’ OVER? SAY IT AIN’T SO. June 17 1989

    " e.pages = ["

    For those of you smart enough to only get your news from us, let this piece break it for you: Dick bit the dust. Yep. Now, forgive me for talking about such an esteemed statesman like a retired prize fighter, but you really had to see him in his prime. Watching him bob-and-weave ol’ George in ‘72 before smacking him so hard against the canvas that it made Gerry sign that ADA law—well, I may just be nostalgic, but you don’t see pols like that today. And while they’ll never admit it, you can bet that everyone from Sacramento to Washington is letting out a sigh of relief, hoping that the curse is finally gone.

    ", "

    What’s this curse, you ask? Well, for those of you who haven’t spent a night with a white-knuckled, sweaty flack from a DuPont Circle dive bar, I’ll fill you in. When they threw Dick out of D.C. like a ratted-out sofa, he swore that if they didn’t want this two-termer, they’d never have one again. And it looks like he's a better sorcerer than he was a president, because this sure was a promise made, promise kept. His VP was a gimme, of course, and sad sack Gerry would’ve been, too, if the President of the Jodie Foster Fan Club didn’t throw in the towel for him at the finish line. Edwin squeaked by on the heartbreak, and we all heard the guffaws coming from Yorba Linda when he was straight-up, no-contest convicted.", "Poor old Dianne, our third Golden Stater in ten years, never had a hope after that. Jack ran up the score on Her Excellency until His Excellency was thrown out of the game by Lloyd, the latest hick we call the President.

    What to make of this bunch? Dr. Kissinger has taken to calling them the absentee Presidents, architects of an absentee America. I, dear reader, agree, and ask: is that really such a bad thing? What’s so sad about this lack of leadership? Am I supposed to be scared to see China reaching out to the world again? Are people dying in the streets of San Francisco because Grenada got rid of the Queen? And does anyone really care, ten years after the fact, that we gave up a goddamn lease in the jungle? Maybe a little benign neglect was just what the doctor ordered for the rest of the world. And, let’s be honest: there’s no curse. Our Presidents are one-termers and half-termers because America is a one-term and half-term country. This is the nation of TV dinners, MTV, fast food. Steady leadership isn’t in our attention span. So, sorry, Herr Doktor, but you’re probably gonna see Lloyd swapped with Bob, and Bob swapped with Mario, and Mario swapped with whoever-the-hell. It’s just our DNA. And the human race is better off for it."] e.image = "../../../../../static/mod_media/1972Nixon_NixonAgnew_44.png"; return construct(0); } else if (demnomLevel == 7 && out == "win" && watergateconfessLevel == 1 && quickstats[0] > 324) { e.header = "

    Remarks by the former President at the 1996 Republican National Convention, Los Angeles, California

    " e.pages = ["

    THE FORMER PRESIDENT: Thank you. Thank you very much. Now, if you’ll excuse just a little parental pride, I am very proud of the Governor of Connecticut, and I am equally proud of a certain Texas delegate, who waged an honorable campaign, and almost was elected Governor of the great state of Texas, Jeb Bush.

    [A few scattered cheers]", "Eh-heh. Well, as we go through the rest of this convention, I think it’s important to take a second to look back at how far we have come. We’ve accomplished a lot together, as a party, since the last time we came together four years ago. I have been so proud to stand with you all in our fight for strong families, strong values, and a strong national checkbook, even through the hard—

    [Some booing]", "—even in the moments where we had to make hard decisions, yes. But I also think it’s all too fitting to take a moment to honor the passing of one of our party’s greatest men, a great Californian, President Nixon. I was honored to call him a great friend and mentor, and his advice was indispensable to me at all of the critical moments during my time in office. When the Soviets attacked those fighting for the cause of freedom in Afghanistan and Southern Africa. When the lawless government in Peking tried to buy their way into recognition. When so many stood against us in our fight to bring justice to a lawless dictator and take an American canal back for Americans, President Nixon was always there, just a phone call away, with the kind of wisdom that only comes from a life of doing what’s right.

    [Some cheers]", "Thank you, thank you. He’ll always be in our hearts. But we must not let the first convention any of us can remember without the man so many of us simply called The President also be the moment the Grand Old Party stepped away from his legacy. Two years ago, the voters were clear. America is tired of Little Jim and the liberals. But we also have to meet the voters where they—

    [Loud boos]

    —we need to meet them where they are! That’s what President Nixon did. That’s—", "

    THE CONVENTION: Pat! Pat! Pat! Pat!

    THE FORMER PRESIDENT: Uhhh…absolutely! He never could have done it without her. One of our greatest first ladies. Besides Barbara, of course. You know, it makes me smile knowing that they’re back—

    THE AUDIENCE: PAT! PAT! PAT! PAT!

    THE FORMER PRESIDENT: —back together once more. And I’m sure the President would have swelled with pride to see that America came to love her as much as—Oh.

    ", "
